instance_methods.doc:
Perform search using given plain query and arguments and builds ` but also allow to preload
related records using `#preload` method nad respects `#none`
instance_methods.summary: Perform search using given plain query and arguments and builds ` but also allow to preload related records using #preload method nad respects #none
instance_methods.args_html: (query : String, args : Array(DBAny) = [] of DBAny)

def.name: find_by_sql
def.body:
results = [] of T
if do_nothing?
  return results
end
T.actual_table_field_count
read_adapter.query(query, args) do |rs|
  begin
    rs.each do
      results << (T.new(rs))
    end
  rescue e : Exception
    rs.read_to_end
    raise(e)
  end
end
add_preloaded(results)

def.body:
if do_nothing?
  return [] of T
end
T.actual_table_field_count
if @relation_used
  add_aliases
end
if @eager_load
  return to_a_with_relations
end
result = [] of T
read_adapter.select(self) do |rs|
  rs.each do
    begin
      result << (T.new(rs))
    rescue e : Exception
      rs.read_to_end
      raise(e)
    end
  end
end
add_preloaded(result)

def.name: preload
def.body:
repo = Array(Array(Model::Resource)).new(@bucket.size + 1)
(@bucket.size + 1).times do
  repo << ([] of Model::Resource)
end
collection.each do |c|
  repo[0] << c
end
pk_repo = Array(Hash(DBAny, Array(DBAny))).new(@bucket.size + 1)
(@bucket.size + 1).times do
  pk_repo << ({} of DBAny => Array(DBAny))
end
@bucket.each_with_index do |pair, index|
  pair[1].preload_relation(repo[pair[0]], repo[index + 1].as(Array(Model::Resource)), pk_repo[index])
end

types.name: NestedRelationTree
types.doc: Wrapper class to store information what model relations structure should be loaded in a request.
types.summary: Wrapper class to store information what model relations structure should be loaded in a request.

def.name: add_relation
read
def.body:
h_result = {} of DBAny => T
models = bucket.map do |__arg0|
  __arg0[1].model_class
end
existence = bucket.map do
  {} of DBAny => Set(DBAny)
end
repo = bucket.map do
  {} of DBAny => Model::Resource
end
stack = Array(Model::Resource | ::Nil).new(bucket.size + 1, nil)
rs.each do
  begin
    column_index = T.actual_table_field_count
    current_attributes = build_hash(rs, 0, T.actual_table_field_count)
    pfn = T.primary_field_name
    pfv = current_attributes[pfn]?
    if pfv
    else
      next
    end
    stack[0] =     __temp_42 = pfv
    h_result[__temp_42]? || (h_result[__temp_42] = (T.build(current_attributes, false)).as(T))

    models.each_with_index do |model, i|
      read_relation(rs, model, i, stack, column_index, existence, repo)
      column_index = column_index + model.actual_table_field_count
    end
  ensure
    rs.read_to_end
  end
end
collection = h_result.values
bucket.each do |pair|
  if pair[0] == 0
  else
    next
  end
  collection.each(&.relation_retrieved(pair[1].name))
end
collection

def.name: select_fields
def.body:
eb = query.expression_builder
buff = Array(Criteria).new(@bucket.size + 1)
buff << eb.star
@bucket.each do |pair|
  rel = pair[1]
  table_name = query._table_aliases[rel.name]? || rel.table_name
  buff << (eb.star(table_name))
end
buff

instance_methods.doc:
Creates a clone of the query without specified *parts*.

Allowed values for *parts*:

instance_methods.name: merge
instance_methods.doc:
Merges other query into current one.

This method merges the following query components:

- `JOIN`s
- `GROUP BY`s
- `ORDER`s
- `CTE`s
- `HAVING`s
- `WHERE`s
- do nothing

```
# returns contacts that have main address
addresses_condition = Jennifer::Query["addresses"].where { _main }
Jennifer::Query["contacts"].join("addresses") { _contact_id == _contacts__id }
  .merge(addresses_condition)
```

This method provides mechanism to reuse some predefined queries for involved tables.
It makes real sense when is used in the scope of `ModelQuery` and models.

```
Contacts.all.relation(:addresses).merge(Address.all.main)
```

def.name: merge
def.body:
{% for segment in ["order", "joins", "groups", "ctes"] of ::String %}
          _{{ segment.id }}!.concat(other._{{ segment.id }}!) if other._{{ segment.id }}?
        {% end %}
if other._having?
  @having = if _having?
    _having! & other._having!
  else
    other._having!
  end
end
if other.tree
  set_tree(other.tree)
end
@do_nothing = @do_nothing || other.do_nothing?
self

instance_methods.name: sql_args
instance_methods.doc: Returns array of SQL query arguments.

def.name: sql_args
def.body:
args = [] of DBAny
if select_filterable_arguments?
  args.concat(select_filterable_arguments)
end
if @from.is_a?(Query)
  args.concat((@from.as(Query)).sql_args)
end
if @joins
  _joins!.each do |join|
    args.concat(join.sql_args)
  end
end
if @tree
  args.concat(@tree.not_nil!.sql_args)
end
if @having
  args.concat(@having.not_nil!.sql_args)
end
if @ctes
  _ctes!.each do |cte|
    args.concat(cte.sql_args)
  end
end
if @unions
  _unions!.each do |union_tuple|
    args.concat(union_tuple[:query].sql_args)
  end
end
args

types.name: QueryObject
types.doc:
Base abstract class for query object.

```
class OrderedArticlesQuery < Jennifer::QueryBuilder::QueryObject
  SORTABLE_FIELDS = %w(by_date by_title by_author)

  private getter field : Sting, order : String

  def initialize(relation, field, order)
    super(relation)
    @order = order == "asc" ? order : "desc"
    @field = SORTABLE_FIELDS.includes?(field) ? field : "by_date"
  end

  def call
    relation.order { article_order }
  end

  private def article_order
    Article.c(field).tap { |article_order| article_order.direction = order }
  end
end

class Article < Jennifer::Model::Base
  # ...
  scope :ordered, OrderedArticlesQuery
end

Article.all.ordered("by_date", "desc")
```

def.name: join_condition
def.body:

_primary = primary_field
jt = join_table!
q = (query.join(jt, type: type) do
  (Q.c(_primary)) == (c(_foreign))
end).join(T, type: type) do
  T.primary == (c(association_foreign_key, jt))

instance_methods.name: preload_relation

def.name: preload_relation
def.body:
if collection.empty?
  return
end
_primary = primary_field
if pk_repo.has_key?(_primary)
else
  array = pk_repo[_primary] = Array(DBAny).new(collection.size)
  collection.each do |e|
    array << (e.attribute_before_typecast(_primary))
  end
end
join_fk = "__join_fk__"
query = query(pk_repo[_primary])
fields = query._select_fields
fields << ((QueryBuilder::Criteria.new(foreign_field, join_table!)).alias(join_fk))
new_collection = (query.select(fields)).db_results
name = self.name
if new_collection.empty?
  collection.each(&.relation_retrieved(name))
else
  primary_fields = pk_repo[_primary]
  collection.each_with_index do |mod, i|
    pv = primary_fields[i]
    new_collection.each do |hash|
      if hash[join_fk] == pv
        out_collection << (mod.append_relation(name, hash))
      end
    end
  end
end

mfk = foreign_field
q = T.all.join(join_table!) do
  ((c(afk)) == T.primary) & (_primary_value.is_a?(Array) ? (c(mfk)).in(_primary_value) : (c(mfk)) == _primary_value)
end
if @join_query
  _tree = @join_query.not_nil!
  q.where do
    _tree
  end
else
  q
end

def.name: validate
def.body:
value = opts[:value]
accept = opts[:accept]?
if value.nil?
  return true
end
invalid = if accept.nil?
  ((value != true) && (value != "1")) && (value != "true")
else
  !(accept.not_nil!.includes?(value))
end
if invalid
  record.errors.add(opts[:field], :accepted)
end

def.name: validate
def.body:
field = opts[:field]
confirmation = opts[:confirmation]?
if confirmation.nil?
  return true
end
value = opts[:value]
with_blank_validation(record, field, value, false) do
  if (value.not_nil!.compare(confirmation.not_nil!, !opts[:case_sensitive]?.not_nil!)) == 0
    return true
  end
  record.errors.add(field, :confirmation, options: {:attribute => record.class.human_attribute_name(field)})
end

For more details see `Macros.validates_length`.

class_methods.name: instance

Length validation class.

For more details see `Macros.validates_length`.

instance_methods.name: validate
instance_methods.doc: Validates given *record* based on *args* and *opts*.

def.name: validate
def.body:
field = opts[:field]
value = opts[:value]
allow_blank = opts[:allow_blank]
in_value = opts[:in]?
is = opts[:is]?
minimum = opts[:minimum]?
maximum = opts[:maximum]?
with_blank_validation(record, field, value, allow_blank) do
  size = value.not_nil!.size
  errors = record.errors
  if in_value
    if in_value.max < size
      errors.add(field, :too_long, in_value.max)
    else
      if in_value.min > size
        errors.add(field, :too_short, in_value.min)
      end
    end
  else
    if is && (is != size)
      errors.add(field, :wrong_length, is)
    else
      if minimum && minimum > size
        errors.add(field, :too_short, minimum)
      else
        if maximum && maximum < size
          errors.add(field, :too_long, maximum)
        end
      end
    end
  end
end

macros.doc:
Validates whether the value of the specified attributes are unique across the system.

Because this check is performed outside the database there is still a chance that duplicate values will be
inserted in two parallel transactions. To guarantee against this you should create a unique index on the field.

```
class Country < Jennifer::Model::Base
  mapping(
    # ...
    code: String
  )

  validate_uniqueness :code
end
```
macros.summary: Validates whether the value of the specified attributes are unique across the system.
macros.args_string: (*fields, allow_blank allow_blank_value = false, if if_value = nil)
macros.args_html: (*fields, allow_blank allow_blank_value = false, if if_value = nil)

def.name: validates_uniqueness
def.body:
# raise a compile time error if a uniqueness validator is specified

        
# that does not define any properties

        
{% if fields.empty?
  raise("A uniqueness check requires at least one field")
end %}


        validates_with_method(
%validate_method
, if: 
{{ if_value }}
)

        
# generate a query that fetches records based on the marked

        
# properties of the current entity

        
# (e.g. ... WHERE id = <id> AND name = <name> AND config = <config> ...)

        
{% normalized_fields = fields.map(&.id) %}


        
{% fields_condition = normalized_fields.map do |field|
  ".where { self.class._#{field} == #{field} }"
end.join("") %}


        
# builds a unique identifier for this set of properties

        
# (e.g. for uniqueness properties `:a`, `:b` this results in `:a_b`)

        
{% fields_identifier = normalized_fields.join("_") %}


        
# :nodoc:

        def 
%validate_method

          ::Jennifer::Validations::Uniqueness.instance.validate(
            self,
            field: :
{{ fields_identifier.id }}
,
            
# pass on nil here to signal nil values in record

            value: 
{{ normalized_fields }}
.all?(&.nil?) ? nil : 
{{ normalized_fields }}
,
            allow_blank: 
{{ allow_blank_value }}
,
            query: self.class
{{ fields_condition.id }}

          )
        
end

macros.name: validates_with
macros.doc:
Passes the record off to an instance of the class specified and allows them to add errors based on more complex conditions.

```
class EnnValidator < Jennifer::Validations::Validator
  def validate(record : Passport)
    record.errors.add(:enn, "Invalid enn") if record.enn!.size < 4
  end
end

class Passport < Jennifer::Model::Base
  mapping(
    enn: {type: String, primary: true}
  )

  validates_with EnnValidator
end
```
macros.summary: Passes the record off to an instance of the class specified and allows them to add errors based on more complex conditions.

macros.name: validates_with_method
macros.doc:
Adds a validation method to the class.

```
class User < Jennifer::Model::Base
  # ...

  validates_with_method :thirteen

  def thirteen
    errors.add(:id, "Can't be 13") if id == 13
  end
end
```
macros.summary: Adds a validation method to the class.

instance_methods.name: validate
instance_methods.doc: Validates given *record* based on *args* and *opts*.

def.name: validate
def.body:
field = opts[:field]
value = opts[:value]
allow_blank = opts[:allow_blank]
greater_than = opts[:greater_than]?
greater_than_or_equal_to = opts[:greater_than_or_equal_to]?
equal_to = opts[:equal_to]?
less_than = opts[:less_than]?
less_than_or_equal_to = opts[:less_than_or_equal_to]?
other_than = opts[:other_than]?
odd = opts[:odd]?
even = opts[:even]?
with_blank_validation(record, field, value, allow_blank) do
  value = value.not_nil!
  errors = record.errors
  if greater_than.try(&.>=(value))
    errors.add(field, :greater_than, {:value => greater_than})
  end
  if greater_than_or_equal_to.try(&.>(value))
    errors.add(field, :greater_than_or_equal_to, {:value => greater_than_or_equal_to})
  end
  if equal_to.try(&.!=(value))
    errors.add(field, :equal_to, {:value => equal_to})
  end
  if less_than.try(&.<=(value))
    errors.add(field, :less_than, {:value => less_than})
  end
  if less_than_or_equal_to.try(&.<(value))
    errors.add(field, :less_than_or_equal_to, {:value => less_than_or_equal_to})
  end
  if other_than.try(&.==(value))
    errors.add(field, :other_than, {:value => other_than})
  end
  if odd && (even?(value))
    errors.add(field, :odd)
  end
  if even && (odd?(value))
    errors.add(field, :even)
  end
end

def.name: validate
def.body:
field = opts[:field]
value = opts[:value]
allow_blank = opts[:allow_blank]
with_blank_validation(record, field, value, allow_blank) do
  _query = opts[:query]?.not_nil!.clone
  if record.new_record?
  else
    _query.where do
      primary != record.primary
    end
  end
  if _query.exists?
    record.errors.add(field, :taken)
  end
end

types.name: Validator
types.doc:
Base validation class.

Take into account that Validator implement singleton pattern. This means that
only one instance of each validator will be created cross the application. As a result #validate
method should be pure.

To implement own validator just inherit and define #validate class, which accepts *record* as a first
argument

```
class CustomValidator < Jennifer::Validations::Validator
  def validate(record, field, message = nil)
    if record.attribute(field) == "invalid"
      record.errors.add(field, message || "blank")
    end
  end
end
```

def.name: blank_validation
def.body:
if allow_blank
  if value.nil?
    return
  end
else
  if value.nil?
    record.errors.add(field, :blank)
    return false
  end
end
true

types.name: Base
types.doc:
Base class for a database [view](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/View_(SQL)).

The functionality provided by view is close to the one of `Model::Base` but has next limitations:

* supports only `after_initialize` callback
* doesn't support any relations
* has no persistence mechanism
* doesn't support virtual attributes

```
class FemaleContact < BaseView
  mapping({
    id:   Primary32,
    name: String,
    }, false)
  end
end
```

instance_methods.name: reload
instance_methods.doc:
Reloads the record from the database.

This method finds record by its primary key and modifies the receiver in-place.

```
user = AdminUser.first!
user.name = "John"
user.reload # => #<AdminUser id: 1, name: "Will">
```

def.name: reload
def.body:
this = self
(self.class.all.where do
  this.class.primary == this.primary
end.limit(1)).each_result_set do |rs|
  init_attributes(rs)
end
self

types.name: Materialized
types.doc:
Base class for a database [materialized view](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/View_(SQL)#Materialized_views).

The only difference from `Base` is one additional method `.refresh` which allows refreshing data of the view.
Also this class usage makes sense only if you use PostgreSQL as only it has native support of materialized views.

class_methods.doc: Refresh materialized view data in th DB.

types.name: Slice
types.doc:
A `Slice` is a `Pointer` with an associated size.

While a pointer is unsafe because no bound checks are performed when reading from and writing to it,
reading from and writing to a slice involve bound checks.
In this way, a slice is a safe alternative to `Pointer`.

A Slice can be created as read-only: trying to write to it
will raise. For example the slice of bytes returned by
`String#to_slice` is read-only.
types.summary: A Slice is a Pointer with an associated size.
